items.synopsis: eHarmony is hit with a lawsuit by the consumer watchdog, alleging the dating site breached Australian consumer law by making misleading statements about the pricing, renewal and cancellation of its memberships.

image.altText: An older man wearing a blue suit and tie and glasses sits in a room with a portrait of Australia's Parliament House behind him.

items.synopsis: Outgoing RBA governor Philip Lowe has delivered his final public speech before handing over to Michele Bullock next week, admitting the central bank did "too much" after the pandemic "with the benefit of hindsight". Follow live.

title.children: Lowe admits RBA 'did too much' when it came to interest rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Time for a quick markets check - and remember about midday when I said there were only three companies in the top 200 that weren't losing value? Well there are more now. Leading the pack is lithium miner Liontown (see my earlier post for more on that). It's a bit of a mixed bag among the top 10. There are some mining, medical, energy and financial stocks in there. Here's the state of play: BHP continues to be drag today as it trades ex-dividend. It's down more than five per cent, but it's not the worst performer this afternoon. That trophy goes to Super Retail Group. All sectors are in the red today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The ASX extends losses, but there are a few bright spots

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lithium player, Liontown has assets in Western Australia and we all know it's a commodity in hot demand because we need it to power batteries. Other companies are eyeing it off. On Monday this week another lithium miner Albemarle upped its offer to buy Liontown, increasing it to $3 a share, valuing Liontown at $6.6 billion. The $3 offer was higher than Albemarle's $2.50 offer back in March - Liontown rejected that back then saying it was far too low. Liontown shares rose to about $2.89 on Monday, but this afternoon they've soared again, jumping 8.3 per cent to now be valued at that Albemarle offer of $3 a share. It's fulling speculation there may be a rival bid in the works for Liontown, with some reports saying i ron ore mogul Gina Rinehart could be behind it. She is said to hold just under a 5 per cent stake in the company already. Albemarle has been pursuing Liontown since October last year, when it made a $2.20 a share offer.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is Gina Rinehart in pursuit of Lithium miner Liontown, as its stock surpasses takeover offer

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Let's reflect for a moment on a point Lowe made earlier in his speech about inflation. He noted that inflation had been wildly different during his time as RBA governor â and more than it had been in two decades. When he began as RBA governor, inflation was below that sweet spot of the 2-3% range we hear about so often, and as we know, inflation rose to its highest level in more than 30 years recently. Overall, he said underlying inflation was averaging 2.7% in his seven-year term, while headline inflation was around 3%. But he does expect that inflation will swing more wildly than it has ever before because of the increased prevalence of supply shocks (like what we saw during the pandemic) plus c limate change, energy transitions and changing demographics. "My view is that it will be difficult to return to the earlier world in which inflation tracked in a very narrow range," he said. That doesn't mean the end of inflation targeting, however â he remains a strong advocate for that 2-3% range.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lowe expects inflation will be more volatile in the years ahead
